[None]
The existence of (40, -11) -- why?!? I mean, why?!? Even having explored all of Balixt and traversed Spignysos to retrieve the AR-57, I have not encountered another level as downright frustrating as this one.

Let me describe the joy: A double-thick layer of purple regenerator bricks at the bottom, followed by a layer of indestructible bricks with only a 2-wide opening, and copious amounts of [I] 'powerups'. And to top it all off, four of those bricks that pump out new blocks each time you hit them and shift the rest of the playing field up, down, left, or right. It took all four of my extra lives, plus two lives from 'Safety' powerups, and even then I only survived because of a last-minute [H] and [M] combo on my last ball.

Avoid (40, -11), unless you enjoy yelling at your screen.

On august 7, 2008
[None]
haha, yeah i remember being on edge for just about every level on cilorile, but i think i only died about 4 times in the end.

basically you want to AIM for the guardians early on - when the ball is slowest. I figured that i was pretty much guaranteed to hit them at some point so i'd rather do it on my own terms - a slower ball gives you longer to react and catch the ball still, and it also means that if you aim for it you're ready to dodge it immediately.

other than that transformations are your saviour on this planet, and be careful when picking up volts because they, along with multiball or a very fast ball, can take away your chance to predict a guardian and therefore lose your lives.

You can break your radar only once between fixing.

So if your cleanup missions is in an anti-radar field, do the whole cleanup before fixing your radar

If your radar isn't broken, you WILL break it if you play an anti-radar level.

On january 2, 2010
bur2000
If you're going to join FURI, you can save a lot of and earn by going a special route:


1) Head to Khorlan and return Salmeen
-> 50 + Extra Life
2) Pick up the alien on Khorlan at [177][-195], he wants to go to Holovan
-> 3270
3) Go to the wormhole at [62][-142] which brings you near Holovan
4) Go to Holovan and pick up the alien at [-154][108], he wants to go to Nalikors

To join FURI you have to leave the belt before 52 cleanups AND you have to land on Nalikors and talk to some guy in a house.

On january 28, 2010
npfan
Bloodbath, if you are able to do these steps correctly, you will be able to complete your transport mission:

1. Go to [-86][83] to get a [P] powerup
2. Do not use any missiles until you're starting [-90][86]
3. Use your missiles to destroy the metal bricks
3a. On the bottom-right side of the level, there is an area of bricks that look like this:
XXXX
ooXo
FFFF

X = metal brick
o = normal brick
F = ferrous (brown) brick

Try to destroy a certain ferrous brick so you have this:
XXXX
ooXo
F FF

Aim one of your missiles at that missing spot without losing a life. However, if you think you will do better firing two missiles with the full row of ferrous bricks, go ahead.
4. If you are still unable to complete the level, go back and forth between [-86][83] and [-90][86] until you are successful.

Hope this helps.

The game is designed for the to go off the screen left and right as it allows for better control of the ball at the corners of the screen. For example if a ball was returning right at the bottom right hand corner of the screen and the was unable to leave the side of the screen the ball could be guaranteed to hit the very right hand side of the and bounce off the at a tight angle.

Allowing the to leave the screen means that when the ball is coming down at one of the corners it means that the player can make the ball hit any part of the depending on where they want it to go.

With regards to the aimer going off the top of the screen, I feel this is a problem, however it doesn't take long to get used to it. I personally haven't done that in a long time.

On june 3, 2010
[1369547]
Pythagorean theorem can be used for approximation.

For "real" calculations, I recommend using the folowing formula:
A(x1, y1); B(x2, y2)

|AB| [square] = (x1 - x2) [square] + (y1 - y2) [square]

Notes: [square] means ^2 (i don't know how to make it clearer )
Also, you will need to calculate (arithmetic) radix to get the exact value, because with the formula I gave you will get it squared By the way, I am not a math geek/nerd, we learned this lesson a couple of days ago
On june 3, 2010
lwxtz2004
C'Ã©tait mieux avant !
Hi,

I know Pythagorean theorem and didn't need a reminder, thanks
I used to do math research
What I said before is that you definitely cannot apply it to measure AB distances. For example :

Euclidean distance between [0][100] and [100][0] is given by the theorem you've quoted, and is equal to 100*(square root of 2) ~ 141 ...
AB distance from [0][100] to [100][0] is equal to 200
On june 3, 2010
piet23
true, pythagoras is of absolutely no use here.. you should take a look at it differently i'm gonna try to explain it.. you have to take the longest distance of which you know you can use all your "engine points" for example if you can travel at most 6 sectors and 4 in unexplored area's and you want to travel from [0][0] to [80][30] you can travel with 6 sectors/capsule untill you reach [60][30] at that point you still have 20 sectors for the 'x-coordinate' to go which means another 20/4 = 5 moves.. this gives a total of 20 moves while dividing the sum of 80 and 30 by 6 would give 110/6=18.33=19 capsules.. in this case the difference isn't so big, but if you take something like from [-30][0] to [150][10] it matters a lot.. if the x or y value is more than 2 times as big as the other, you can calculate the number of capsules you use by just dividing the largest difference by 4. if the biggest distance is less than twice as much as the other, like from [20][40] to [60][70] you can divide it by 6.. (assuming you have the earlier mentioned engine and radar in unexplored area) therefore you should also take into account whether an area is already explored or not, since it can make a huge difference in how far you can travel! (for example i have the best possible engine without terre, so in explored area's i can travel 7 sectors in one direction, but in an unexplored area only 4) hope this makes some things clear, i know it's a long story
On june 3, 2010
piet23
oh one more note:
if the biggest distance is less than twice as much as the other, like from [20][40] to [60][70] you can divide it by 6 what you have to divide by 6 is the sum of the x and y differences; in this case (60-20)+(70-40)=70.

As far as I know, it is completely based on a personal psychology and perception of the world. If it seems to you that the virtual world is more realistic than the real world (it seems to me all the time), you could have a problem because your punishment/reward part of the brain is/was too stimulated with virtual pleasures.

I have read a study on that topic not too long ago Basically it says that most (if not all) gamers feel stronger emotions when they succeed something in a "virtual world" than if they succeed in a "real world." IMHO, that is completely based on perceptions.

Although, I feel obligated to say that "virtual world" is just a projection (or a sandbox version) of a "real world"

On june 6, 2010
piet23
Ok, second try

true, pythagoras is of absolutely no use here.. you should take a look at it differently i'm gonna try to explain it..

if you can travel at most 6 sectors (V5 engine) and 4 in unexplored area's (level 2 radar) and you want to travel from [0][0] to [80][30] you can travel with 6 sectors/ untill you reach [60][30]

(since you can travel at most 4 sectors in 1 direction, which leaves 2 sectors for the other direction)

at that point you still have 20 sectors for the 'x-coordinate' to go which means another 20/4 = 5 moves.. this gives a total of 20, while dividing the sum of 80 and 30 by 6 would give 110/6=18.33=19

in this case the difference isn't so big, but if you take something like from [-30][0] to [150][10] (180/10) it matters a lot..

The main rule you can remember is this one:

if the x or y value you have to travel is more than 2 times as big as the other, you can calculate the number of you have to use by dividing the largest difference by 4.

Example: from [0][0] to [120][30]. the x-difference is 120, the y-difference is 30. 120 is 4 times as large as 30, so you have to divide 120 by 4 which gives a total of 30

if the biggest distance is less than twice as much as the other, like from [20][40] to [60][70] (40/30) you can divide the sum of the differences (40+30 = 70) by 6 which gives 70/6=11,67=12 (assuming you have the earlier mentioned engine and radar in unexplored area)

therefore you should also take into account whether an area is already explored or not, since it can make a huge difference in how many you have to use

(for example, i have the best possible engine without terre(V6), so in explored area's i can travel 7 sectors in one direction, but in an unexplored area only 4)

I hope my story is understandable now.. if you have any further questions or don't understand how you can apply this to another engine or radar, just me

A rule of thumb is that your cleanup is limited to the coordinates based on what number you're on. For example, your 52nd cleanup would not go too far beyond [52] in either coordinate. In theory, you could have your first cleanup outside the Karbonis Belt around the 65th cleanup. However, that is very unlikely. (None of my first 87 cleanups have been outside the belt.)

On september 28, 2010
[1413387]
System restore won't work on files, only installed programs etc.

Download a file recovery program as soon as possible, there's a big chance you'll be able to get your file back.

When you delete something from you hard drive, it simply marks the data as room in which something can be saved over, so the data could sit there for years before it's overwritten even when permanently deleted from your recycle bin. All the data will still be there which is why file recovery programs can easily pull it back up.

On may 22, 2011
[1369547]
You can dodge Kashuats about the same way you learn how to dodge Guardians.

Just slowly move your paddle from the side of your screen to your ball. So, if your ball is going to fall on the left side, start on the right and move toward your ball fast enough to dodge the shots.

That's how I did it. But, on the other hand, I had 5 drones

On may 23, 2011
[1369547]
Oh, and I forgot to mention something

Set your mouse sensitivity to the most sensitive, and then move your pad. The shots will safely land outside the playing window and you are safe.

Also, use pause-dodging whenever you need to teleport (I presume that you have the Medallion) to a safe location.

Kompera
The level at [-22][-27] is driving me CRAZY!One thing it does have is two missiles. Get to a merchant and top off your 7 missile capacity. Then use two when you're sure you'll be able to catch the two that drop. Then use 7 more and you should be able to poke enough holes in the unbreakable bricks and get this level completed.
Also remember that sometimes a layer of unbreakable bricks is awesome. Once you get it up there it can stay there for a long time and break all kinds of bricks for you. Especially if it's a Volt. Volt can also break bricks through the unbreakable bricks, although this is a slow process.

The merchant at -14, -18 has several helpful capsules which will also be helpful.

On january 2, 2013
Launcelot

bully09, since you've ran out of missiles that would make this level fairly easy, you can try playing with the auto javelin. There aren't many bricks to destroy so the javelin shouldn't take long to kick in. While buying time until it does, lose 1 ball on purpose and try to hold the other right in the center of the screen just under those steel bricks forming a "T". If you succeed, use the javelin to clear either the far left, or far right column first. These are the most loaded columns so if you clear them first, the next javelin will kick in much faster, making your life easier. Then move your way to the next columns. At some point you will lose your life because of the ball's speed, but hopefully your remaining lives will be enough to pull this off and literally get the hell out of the level. Anyway, that's what I'd do.. worth a shot..

On may 21, 2013
Kompera
kpcsI am trying to learn how to land on planets and I'm having a super awful time of trying to do it. Is this me being incompetant and newbish, or is it practically impossible for everyone until buying extensions?

Here's my best advice for a new planet lander:

Immediately after you hit the land button, move your mouse cursor to the top middle of the game area. This will let you start your descent with your envelope level, so using the thrusters won't send you flying all over the place or starting upside down.

Slow down once you get near the surface, even stopping downward motion entirely if it doesn't look like you can land right below your envelope. If you can't land there, tip the envelope gently by moving the mouse just a little bit left or right and apply a little bit of thrust to move over to a spot you can land.

Wild mouse movements or too much thrust will have you flying all over the place without control.

For me the sector has to have at least close to 150 minerals or more to be worthy of visiting, either landing or just playing a level that is not in my route. For example if I have 3 levels that take me a little off route, they gotta have at least close to 450 minerals combined otherwise I'll keep my CHS and won't visit. In my criteria I also take into account the number of CHS I may have to use to get back into my route after the deviation. For example there may be a level with 400 minerals alone that looks like a good idea to visit, but if I have to use 5 CHS to get there and get back into my route and if the levels in between aren't worthy, then minerals per CHS won't justify the visit. As for landing, I'm gonna land if the level has close to 150 minerals or more.

Here's some advice:

As soon as you finish a level and you don't plan to immediately play another level, click the wrench in the lower-left corner to open the References screen. That way, there's no way you can accidentally activate the retrofuser.

Once you reach Terre your generator will be automatically upgraded to level 6 and you will never be able to have level 7 because it is not up for sale anywhere. On may 30, 2013
[1382851]

I figure since the "being too open" bit in my last post was a little weird I should explain. Why would Alphabounce be a reminder of something philosophical? Basically, I find that it's making a sense of time scale. It helps me understand an interval which is generally impossible to understand. It's like this: time scale of a week or so? Measure progress by getting problem sets done and solving similar problems. A semester? Measure progress by completing courses and taking qualifying exams. Those are short enough term where I can truly see the progress. Multi-year, like fitness, learning an instrument, or becoming a real academic? It's hard to really see things as progressing when they're going that slowly, so having something that progresses on that time scale but keeps moving forward (e.g. Alphabounce) gives a good sense of perspective. That's what bothered me about hitting that one button: it kinda broke the sense of perspective for a minute. It's back, though, so...not going to stop now! Just going to take a side-trip.

On december 19, 2013
Launcelot

Purchasing multiple for in one visit can be a very irritating procedure because you buy them one by one. Try clicking the button and then the pay button 600 times. In any case, if anyone plans to buy a lot in a single visit, I recommend you avoid having your profile page open while you make your transactions, because they take even longer. I did it with the missions page open instead and there was no delay, just the "connecting to server" message for about a second, sometimes even less. Took me about 20 minutes. With profile page open you'll need an extra couple of seconds for each, which may not seem too bad, but for 600 you'll waste another 20 minutes. I also had the "connecting to server" message freeze up on me a few times and had to refresh, but no progress was lost.

On march 14, 2014
drakh

You have no radar upgrade, so you can't see much in unexplored areas. Therefore you can't travel there in 1 go. Also, your generator upgrade allows you to move a maximum of 3 squares in visible zones. As a comparison, here's the situation with radar 1 and generator 5. Mind you, neither my radar nor my generator are upgraded to the max yet, that's just to show you how the situation evolves when you get some upgrades.
The radar is the most important upgrade when you want to move a lot in unknown sectors; instead, the generator allows you to move more in previously explored sectors. Check the wiki for detailed explanations.

NocturnaI'm on Samosa and just got my first PID piece... But I can't figure out how to get my jetpack to activate to get back in my envelope.

It's a real pain in the envelope. You have to double click and hold really fast. Some techniques for making it easier include:

1) Stand on the highest point you can find, jump off, click and hold.
2) Face away from the direction you plan to jump.

Good luck!

On february 19, 2015
Launcelot

While there are levels that favor both, at the end of the day I think you get used to either faction you choose. For example I gave FURI a try once (asked a real life friend to play one of his levels on his computer) and the envelope felt so small I had a hard time controlling the ball. When I asked him how he can play like that, he said he didn't think his envelope was small, he knew it was smaller technically but it never felt that way. Similarly he would find my envelope big enough to hold the ball forever and the lack of asphalt ball resulting in levels taking forever to complete. Whichever faction you choose, overtime you get used to its weakness and learn to exploit its strength, and all that happens unconsciously and that is why anyone you ask they'll say it feels great being with either FURI or ESCorp. I've always said I wish I had the asphalt ball but I'm sure I'd still have a very hard time dealing with the smaller envelope. Grass is always greener on the other side... until it's yours.

That far away from the origin you don't get any more merchants to resupply with missiles, which means you can basically use one per level, otherwise the Perpetual Synthesys Motor can't keep up with regenerating them.
